instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
Working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bord, no fan spin

Measurements

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  12.62v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> 12.63
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> 12.63v

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.34

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 5.15v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.219v  0.401v in diode mode

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3v

CPU getting hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8080</CHIP> measurements

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_FET_RAMP</SIGNAL> was shorted so replaced <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> and short is gone

Now to the interesting. All s4 lines are gone and dont have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>

Tested to change <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> back to the original one and all lines are back but <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.219v.
Tested another new <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> and All s4 lines are gone again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message: Sounds like bad <CHIP>U8080S</CHIP> to me. Remove it and check for short on <SIGNAL>FET_RAMP</SIGNAL> pin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message: already done done that, with <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> removed no short on <SIGNAL>FET_RAMP</SIGNAL>. with new <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> all s4 rails are gone

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
Something powered from <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> generates the problem.
Maybe CPU power supply, audio or backlight circuit.
Check first <CAPACITOR>C6412</CAPACITOR>/22/32/42, as common issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message: but dont even have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> after change of <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
I bet you have a pulse.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
after ultrasonic



<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.16v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> . 3.3v

fan spin for 15 sec then stops then speed up and constant spinning


cpu getting hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message: So have you plugged in a screen to see if it boots now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
its still not booting 

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> short to ground 0.3 ohm  and 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message: yes one more donor board =) Boring with this cards piled for a year.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no fan spin
threads.message:
Didn't check VCORE before start repair???
Diode mode on big coils, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 are the FIRST things MUST be done when you put the board on the desk; BEFORE connecting any power!
